Three photographs of Greeley, Colorado businesses. The upper left photograph shows an exterior view of Abe Winograd's poultry business. dc:dc.dc:title: Pajama Party for Patients of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 3 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on front of photograph: ''A pajama party, on sun porch, My wheel chair, Old Bldg.'' Handwritten on envelope: ''#429 JCRS 1929s.'' On back of photograph: ''JCRS, I made the paper hats, for this occasion, c 1928, from album of Bertha 'Mickey' Marks, donor Mrs. Ruth Cluff, #429.''

Unidentified female patients enjoy a pajama party at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.
Donated by Ruth Cluff.

dc:dc.dc:title: William Goldblatt and Family
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
This is a copy of the original photograph.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 45.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Denver Newton St. 1914, William and Helen Goldblatt, Ruth and Marvin Goldblatt children.''

William Goldblatt and his family stand on the porch of their home at 1473 Newton Street in Denver, Colorado. Goldblatt followed an unusual profession for a Denver Jewish citizen when he became a local fireman. Later, he became a Denver police officer and wore badge number one. He is pictured here in police uniform with his wife, Helen, and children Ruth and Marvin.
Donated by Helene Hoffman.

dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Their Green Mountain Dairy was located at the southwest corner of West 1st Avenue and Wadsworth Boulevard on land bought from the George Devinny family. (Photo courtesy of Jake Lederman)."

Jake Lederman helps his father Harsh Lederman deliver milk by horse drawn carriage, in downtown Denver, Colorado in March, 1911. dc:dc.dc:title: Label Ginsburg Standing in His Ginsburg's Grocery Store
dc:dc.dc:format: 2 items (2 photographs), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 43.

Handwritten on envelope: "# 207 Label Ginsburg, in grocery store, c 1925 info inside check copy". Typewritten tag located inside original envelope: "Label Ginsberg In his grocery store Denver, C. 1925". Handwritten notes on back of photograph: "Approximately 1925 #207 MMJ 15 8/78 Mr. Louis Ginsburg (Verben) 14th at Grove St. Husband of Mollie Ginsburg. Father of :Rose Greenblatt (Mrs. Isadore Greenblatt 1576 Osceola) Dr. Hyman Ginsburg 3124 Van Ness Fresno, Calif 98704 Joe Ginsburg, Acct. 955 Eudora 80222 Picture sent in by: Faye Langer (Mrs. William Lauger) Mr. and Mrs. William Lauger 418 Swain Court Stockton, Calif 95207 5 5/16 x 3 5/8 Religion Cut Phillips Fri 9".

Label Ginsburg is standing in front of Ginsburg's grocery counter wearing a suit and bowler hat. Canned and dry goods are displayed on the shelves as well as a large sign for Hills Brothers Coffee. The store was located at 1401 Grove St., Denver, Colorado in Denver's Westside Colfax Jewish community. When a sign painter made a mistake and spelled the Ginsberg surname with a "u" instead of an "e," Label changed the family name to Ginsburg.
Donated by Dorothea Langer in September of 1978.

dc:dc.dc:title: Patients Undergoing Heliotherapy at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 6 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 83.
On envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities.'' On back of photograph: ''JCRS TB Patients undergoing Heliotherapy, 1920s.''

Unidentified tuberculosis patients undergoing heliotherapy at the Main Medical Building of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Fresh air and sunshine were popular treatments for tuberculosis and patients were encouraged to spend time outside. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

dc:dc.dc:title: Marchick Store
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

On envelope: ''#1065 Lillian and Sam Marchick Sam and Ben Marchick.'' On back of photograph: ''Cheyenne, Wyoming Sam Marchick and Sons store, Sandy Viniks maternal grandfather, Same Marchick on left, his son Ben in center.'' On back of second photograph, #1065, Sam Marchick, Joe Marchick, Marchick & Son, Cheyenne.''

Store owner Sam Marchick, left, his son in center, and an unidentified man and woman at right, in Marchick's Cheyenne, Wyoming store. A sign in back of large trunk reads "Shoe sale - pick em out." Another sign that is displayed between the two Marchick men, states, "Sale on pants." Samuel Marchick and his wife, Lillie (Rice), were born in Ostrovo, Poland. Sam Marchick came to the United States in 1904 and sent for his wife and children: Joseph, Benjamin, Jacob, Mary, Arline and Faye. The family operated a new and used clothing store and a pawn shop, and lived above the store.

dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Full-length portrait of Israel Kortz in his suit and bowler hat and Rebecca Kortz in a dress and hat. She holds a parasol. The Kortz family originated in Brest Litovsk, Russia, and arrived in Denver, Colorado around 1885. dc:dc.dc:title: Exterior of Hebrew Education Alliance
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Courtesy of Charles McNamara.
Photograph was mislaid and was replaced by another print.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 68.

The Hebrew Educational Alliance's original building at West Colfax and Meade Street. It was founded in 1932 and became the largest congregation on Denver's west side. The Hebrew Educational Alliance was created as a result of the ''alliance'' between the Beth David Hebrew School Sisterhood and Brotherhood, and the Denver Hebrew Institute. On October 25, 1932, Rabbi Manuel Laderman arrived in Denver to serve as the first Rabbi of the Hebrew Educational Alliance. The combined synagogue and Hebrew School was organized along Orthodox lines. When the Alliance moved into another building, the original building became the Golden West Nursing Home.
Donated by the photographer, Dr. Charles Mcnamara.

Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 85.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Dr. Charles Spivak at his desk, c. 1923.'' Handwritten on back of duplicate photograph: ''Dr. Spivak at his desk c.1920.''

Dr. Charles Spivak sits at his desk with a copy of the Denver Jewish News opened in front of him and a telephone on an extension frame behind him. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians, including Dr. Spivak, and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

dc:dc.dc:title: Patients Undergoing Heliotherapy at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 83.
On envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities.'' On back of photograph: ''JCRS TB Patients undergoing Heliotherapy, 1930s.''

Patients lay in beds pushed out on the porches of the New York Building of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society for sun heliotherapy treatment for tuberculosis. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

Canned goods and staples inside the Londoner Store located at 15th Avenue and Arapahoe Street in Denver, Colorado. The Londoner grocery store was owned by Wolfe Londoner, mayor of Denver from 1889 to 1891.

A group of children, some in robes, sit with the matron and director at the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children. The children were in the care of the home, which later became the National Home for Jewish Children in Denver.

dc:dc.dc:title: Adolph Kiesler at Cornerstone Ceremony for Beth Israel Home
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 11 x 14 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''laying the cornerstone of Beth Israel Hospital, Adolph Kiesler, 1940.''

Adolph Kiesler attends a cornerstone ceremony for Beth Israel Home for the Aged at West 16th Avenue and Lowell Boulevard, Denver, Colorado. He stands in a suit and holds his hat in his left arm while shaking hands with a man in a suit and overcoat. Two men in suits, hats and overcoats stand behind Adolph Kiesler. Two men in work clothes stand behind the cornerstone that is attached to a pulley. ''Home for the Aged 1940 Erected 5700'' is chiseled on the stone. A boy stands, and two boys (one wears a jacket, the others are in shirtsleeves) sit on a brick wall.
Donated by Peggy Lehmann, granddaughter of Adolph Kiesler.
ph747

dc:dc.dc:title: Emanuel Stein Displaying Leisure-O Line of Retail Seafoods
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: "# 386 Stein family of Pueblo, 1900-1960 info inside." Photocopy of handwritten note inside original envelope: "Taken in Pueblo, Colorado between 1913 and 1914. Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein." Handwritten note on back of photocopy: "Emanuel Stein displaying part of his Leisure-O line of retail seafoods sold throughout the west starting in 1939." Handwritten on back of photocopy: "Emanual Stein in Stein Foods, 115 E 4th St, Pueblo, c1960., Business in continuous proprietorship of Stein family for 65 years as of 1981 at original location., #386."
Emanuel Stein is seated behind a table covered with his Leisure-O brand of frozen seafood, which was sold throughout the Western States starting in 1939. This is a photocopy print.
